These previous studies imply that the Arctic radiative response is linked to changes in atmospheric-energy transport into the Arctic, which is controlled by dynamical processes such as large-scale planetary waves, mesoscale cyclones, and the zonal-mean circulation
29 . Hence, dynamically driven energy flux (hereafter, dynamical response) can accelerate or decelerate Arctic warming
30, 31 . In summary, the degree of future Arctic warming should be controlled by the balance between local radiative-feedback processes and horizontally transported dynamical energy-flux changes.
